title: Transform Your Mind: Master Senses for Krishna Bhakti
transliterated_verse: yoginām api sarveṣāṁ mad-gatenāntar-ātmanā śraddhāvān bhajate yo māṁ sa me yuktatamo mataḥ
english_translation: And of all yogīs, he who always abides in Me with great faith, worshiping Me in transcendental loving service, is most intimately united with Me in yoga and is the highest of all.
main_theme: Achieving true sense control through active devotion to Krishna
takeaway: Achieving true sense control and realizing one's spiritual identity comes not just from mechanical practices like pranayama, but through active surrender and fervent begging for Krishna's mercy, thus transforming the mind for His service.
summary_short: This lecture explores the profound journey of sense control, contrasting mechanical Ashtanga Yoga with the devotional approach of Bhakti Yoga. It emphasizes turning the mind inward for Krishna, recognizing our spiritual identity, and actively seeking Krishna's mercy to overcome material attachments and truly engage our senses in devotional service.

themes.title: The Inward Turn: Discovering Spiritual Identity
themes.details: The mind, when absorbed in external sense objects, leads to a dissipated and constantly changing identity, making it difficult to know the real self. By turning the mind completely inward, away from outward sensations, one can purify their identity and clearly distinguish the soul from the material body. This realization is likened to evaporating water from a sweet or extracting oil from a seed, revealing the true essence. This initial understanding of the soul's distinction from matter is called Brahman realization, compared to the sunlight illuminating the sky before the sun (Krishna) has fully risen in the heart.
examples: Sugary sweet mixed with water (obscuring true sweetness)
Ghee and milk, or oil within a seed (requiring processing to reveal essence)

themes.title: Pratyahara: Mechanical vs. Devotional Sense Control
themes.details: Ashtanga yoga employs mechanical processes like Pratyahara (withdrawal of senses) and Pranayama (breath control) to arrest the outward tendency of the mind and senses, similar to caging a bird in a net. An Ashtanga yogi or a Jnani renounces material enjoyment primarily because it causes pain. However, this mechanical suspension of agitation is temporary. A Bhakti-yogi also practices sense control, but their renunciation is rooted in a desire to offer themselves as the 'bhogya' (enjoyed object) to Krishna, the 'bhokta' (supreme enjoyer), rather than merely avoiding pain. This transforms the basis of renunciation into a loving offering.
examples: Patanjali's comparison of catching a bird in a net to controlling senses via pranayama
Tylenol as a temporary suspension of pain, similar to pranayama's temporary suspension of agitation

themes.title: Ahara and Bhogya: The Nature of Enjoyment
themes.details: The term 'Ahara' traditionally refers to food, but in a broader sense, it means enjoyment, as the senses 'eat' or absorb their respective objects (eyes 'eat' forms, ears 'eat' sounds). Material life is characterized by the individual 'eating' or enjoying sense objects. In Krishna consciousness, this concept is completely reversed: the devotee aspires to be the 'bhogya' (the enjoyed object) for Krishna, who is the supreme 'bhokta' (enjoyer). The highest consciousness involves recognizing oneself as the 'food' being eaten by Krishna, marking a complete shift from selfish enjoyment to selfless offering.
examples: Senses 'eating' (enjoying) forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and sensations
The concept of 'aha mannam' where the devotee becomes the enjoyed object for Krishna

themes.title: The Superiority of Bhakti & Active Surrender
themes.details: While mechanical processes like Pranayama can temporarily suspend agitation, they are not sustainable. True and lasting sense control comes from love for Krishna, developed through attentive hearing from a pure devotee. Such hearing awakens affection for Krishna, which is crucial for internalizing the Hare Krishna mantra and directing senses inward. If affection doesn't arise, it indicates either duplicitous tendencies or not hearing from a genuine source. Genuine surrender means actively redirecting the senses towards Krishna, not passively allowing them to wander, realizing that 'one cannot become a yogi' if one is still hankering for sense objects.
examples: Rukmini Devi understanding Krishna by hearing about Him
The prayer 'bhajahure mana shri nandanandanam' (Oh mind, worship Krishna)

themes.title: The Urgency of Begging Krishna for Advancement
themes.details: Most individuals do not possess 'rati' (spiritual attachment) from previous births, making their current spiritual advancement inadequate and even dangerous. Therefore, it is imperative to intensely and consistently beg Krishna and the spiritual master for help in controlling the senses and fixing the mind on the Lord. One should not become complacent or proud about their spiritual situation, as such a mindset can lead to spiritual stagnation or fall down. Active 'vignyapti' (humble petition) is essential for receiving divine mercy and progressing in Krishna consciousness.
examples: The speaker's personal experience of not having rati from previous births
The warning against spiritual pride or idleness, which can lead to spiritual regression

sanskrit_terms.definition_long: Literally 'food,' but in the context of the lecture, it refers to the enjoyment or absorption of sense objects by the senses (e.g., eyes 'eating' forms, ears 'eating' sounds).

sanskrit_terms.definition_short: Withdrawal of the senses from their objects
sanskrit_terms.definition_long: One of the eight limbs of Ashtanga yoga, referring to the conscious effort to detach the senses from external attractions and redirect them internally.
That which is to be enjoyed. In Krishna consciousness, the devotee aspires to be the 'bhogya' for Krishna, meaning to be an object of Krishna's transcendental pleasure.
The one who enjoys. Krishna is described as the supreme 'bhokta' (enjoyer) of all sacrifices and austerities (BG 5.29).
Refers to the state where spiritual knowledge (jnana) is revealed, allowing one to clearly perceive the truth of the Atma (soul) distinct from matter, likened to a sun shining forth.
The individual spirit soul, distinct from the material body, mind, and intelligence.

sanskrit_terms.definition_short: Understanding the distinction of soul from matter
sanskrit_terms.definition_long: The realization of the impersonal Absolute Truth, understanding one's spiritual identity as distinct from the material body and its temporary designations. It is described as a preliminary stage before full Krishna realization.
Undivided and unalloyed devotional service to the Supreme Lord, without any other motive or object of worship.
A mystic yoga system consisting of eight limbs: Yama, Niyama, Asana, Pranayama, Pratyahara, Dharana, Dhyana, and Samadhi, aimed at achieving self-realization through control of the mind and senses.
A limb of Ashtanga yoga involving specific breathing exercises (like kumbhaka rechaka) to regulate the life airs and thereby control the mind and senses.
Specific techniques within pranayama involving holding the breath (kumbhaka) and exhaling (rechaka) to achieve control over the breath and subtle energies.
One of the three modes of material nature (gunas), characterized by activity, agitation, and desire, which binds the living entity to fruitive actions.
The projecting potency of the illusory energy (Maya), which causes the living entity to forget its spiritual identity and become absorbed in material activities and enjoyment.
The feeling of 'mine' or possessiveness. In the context of the lecture, it refers to identifying with Krishna as the enjoyer ('my dear Lord must enjoy me') rather than oneself as the enjoyer.
A humble and earnest prayer or request, often expressing one's difficulties and appealing for divine mercy and guidance.
The initial stage of spontaneous spiritual affection or attachment for Krishna, which develops into prema (pure love of Godhead).
The superlative term used in Bhagavad Gita 6.47 to describe the devotee who worships Krishna with great faith and transcendental loving service, identifying them as the highest among all yogis.

quotes: When the mind is completely turned inward, then one can actually see the real nature of the mind, intelligence, body.
To know the real self, this identity has to become purified.
The soul is the same. Body is the same. Everything appears the same. We can't see any distinction.
This Brahman realization when one understands the distinction between the soul and matter is compared to lightening up the sky. The sun has not risen. Krishna has not arisen.
Only by Ananya Bhakti can I be understood. Only by Bhakti is he realized, not by Jnana, not by any other means.
So Krishna consciousness means to become an Ahara to Krishna.
Material life means that I want to enjoy, I want to eat something. This is material Ahara.
If Krishna is the bhogta, then what am I? I am the bhogya. I am the enjoyed.
The birds which wants to fly are compared to the senses. They want to fly in the sky. They want to fly into the world of sense objects.
The devotee feels that if I enjoy material object, then it stands as an obstacle for me offering myself as an object of enjoyment to my dear Lord.
A devotee also does pratiahara. But instead of putting it on a self, he says, my dear mind, bhajahure mana shri nandanandanam. Hey mind, don't enjoy these objects. Offer this to my dear Lord.
If you simply think I should not be the enjoyer... This is artificial. But if one gives himself as the bhogyam for the Lord, Krishna, you enjoy me.
The last consciousness is that I am the food that is being eaten. Krishna is the enjoyer who is eating. Complete opposite. I am the enjoyed.
Why do I say temporarily suspended? Because it will only work as long as the pranayama is continuing to work.

A devotee should not see anything other than Krishna. He should not hear anything other than Krishna. He should not smell anything other than Krishna. He should not taste anything other than Krishna. He eats Krishna, he sees Krishna, he smells Krishna.
If one is not getting that feeling [affection for Krishna], then either one is definitely having some duplicitous tendency, or definitely one is not hearing from a pure devotee. Either of it is true.
We should not think that, I'll just hear and chant Hare Krishna mantra and then some magic will happen. No, we must actively try to surrender.
Surrender means what? The senses must not go outside. The senses must go only towards Krishna.
The aspiration to go towards the sense objects must be stunted. How is it stunted? By begging at the lotus feet of the Lord, by begging at the lotus feet of the spiritual master.
This level of advancement you have made or we have made is absolutely inadequate. And it's a very dangerous position. So we should immediately start begging Krishna very intensely.

life_applications.principle: Cultivating spiritual identity through inward focus
life_applications.how_to: Practice turning the mind inward, away from external sense objects, to discern the soul from matter and purify one's identity.
life_applications.daily_practice: During chanting or meditation, consciously redirect wandering senses back to the sound vibration of the mantra and Krishna's form. Reflect on the distinction between body and self.
life_applications.expected_outcome: Gradual realization of one's true spiritual identity, reducing attachment to material designations and fostering detachment from temporary roles.

life_applications.principle: Transforming renunciation from mechanical to devotional
life_applications.how_to: Understand that avoiding material enjoyment should stem from a desire to offer oneself as an object of enjoyment (bhogya) to Krishna, rather than merely escaping pain or agitation.
life_applications.daily_practice: Before engaging senses in any activity (eating, seeing, hearing), consciously offer the activity and its potential enjoyment to Krishna. For example, offer food to Krishna before eating; offer one's hearing to Krishna by listening to kirtan or spiritual discourse.
life_applications.expected_outcome: Sense activities become spiritualized, increasing one's connection to Krishna and reducing selfish desire, making renunciation joyful.

life_applications.principle: Active surrender and seeking Krishna's mercy
life_applications.how_to: Recognize the inadequacy of one's own efforts for sense control and actively pray to Krishna and the spiritual master for help in directing the senses.
life_applications.daily_practice: Regularly engage in 'vignyapti' (humble petition) during personal prayer, expressing struggles with sense control and begging for internal focus on Krishna. Do not be idle or proud of current spiritual advancement.
life_applications.expected_outcome: Krishna's mercy helps purify the senses and mind, making it easier to engage in sincere devotional service and overcome material temptations.

life_applications.principle: The power of attentive hearing from pure devotees
life_applications.how_to: Seek out and diligently hear lectures and teachings from authorized, pure devotees to cultivate genuine love and affection for Krishna.
life_applications.daily_practice: Dedicate time each day to listen to discourses by bona fide spiritual masters, focusing on their message about Krishna's glories and the path of bhakti. Observe if affection for Krishna arises in the heart.
life_applications.expected_outcome: Affection and love for Krishna will naturally awaken in the heart, making devotional practices more relishable and effective, leading to a deeper connection with the Lord.

quiz.question: According to the lecture, what happens when the mind is 'completely turned inward'?
options: One experiences great pain and suffering.
One becomes completely indifferent to all external stimuli.
One can see the real nature of the mind, intelligence, and body, distinguishing soul from matter.
One immediately attains liberation from all material desires.
quiz.explanation: The speaker states, 'When the mind is completely turned inward, then one can actually see the real nature of the mind, intelligence, body,' leading to the distinction between the body and the self.

quiz.question: How does the speaker distinguish the 'Pratyahara' of an Ashtanga Yogi from a Bhakti Yogi's approach to sense control?
options: Ashtanga Yogis use mechanical force, while Bhakti Yogis rely solely on prayer.
Ashtanga Yogis desist from enjoyment because it causes pain; Bhakti Yogis renounce to offer enjoyment to Krishna.
Ashtanga Yogis focus on breath regulation, while Bhakti Yogis focus on chanting Hare Krishna.
Ashtanga Yogis aim for Brahman realization, while Bhakti Yogis aim for Vaikuntha.
quiz.explanation: The lecture explains that an Ashtanga Yogi gives up material enjoyment because it causes pain, while a devotee renounces because they want to offer themselves as the 'bhogya' (enjoyed object) to Krishna, not to avoid pain.

quiz.question: What is the 'last consciousness' mentioned by the speaker regarding 'Ahara' (enjoyment)?
options: I am eating and the food is being eaten.
I am the enjoyer of all senses and their objects.
I am the food that is being eaten; Krishna is the enjoyer.
I am neither the enjoyer nor the enjoyed, but an observer.
quiz.explanation: The speaker states, 'The last consciousness is that I am the food that is being eaten. Krishna is the enjoyer who is eating. Complete opposite. I am the enjoyed.'

quiz.question: Why does the speaker emphasize 'begging Krishna intensely' as a crucial process for spiritual advancement?
options: Because it is the only way to gain material opulence and comfort.
Because our current spiritual advancement is often inadequate and dangerous, requiring divine mercy for sense control.
Because Krishna enjoys being begged and will grant any wish indiscriminately.
Because it is a mechanical process of surrender, similar to pranayama.
quiz.explanation: The speaker asserts that 'This level of advancement you have made or we have made is absolutely inadequate. And it's a very dangerous position. So we should immediately start begging Krishna very intensely' to combat external sense attractions and progress spiritually.

quiz.question: The lecture compares 'Brahman realization' (understanding the distinction of soul from matter) to which celestial phenomenon?
options: The full moon at night, illuminating the darkness.
The twinkling of stars in a clear sky.
Sunlight appearing in the sky before the sun (Krishna) has fully risen.
The darkness of a moonless night, representing ignorance.
quiz.explanation: The speaker explains, 'This Brahman realization when one understands the distinction between the soul and matter is compared to lightening up the sky. The sun has not risen. Krishna has not arisen.'

scriptural_references.text_transliteration: yoginām api sarveṣāṁ mad-gatenāntar-ātmanā śraddhāvān bhajate yo māṁ sa me yuktatamo mataḥ
scriptural_references.text_translation: And of all yogīs, he who always abides in Me with great faith, worshiping Me in transcendental loving service, is most intimately united with Me in yoga and is the highest of all.
scriptural_references.context: This verse concludes Chapter 6 and establishes the supremacy of bhakti yoga, highlighting the pure devotee as the 'yuktatama' or the highest among all yogis, a concept central to the lecture's theme of superior sense control.
Mentioned by the speaker as the verse they would continue discussing in the next session, indicating a continuation of the theme of spiritual practice and liberation.

youtube_description:
Jai Sachinandana Krsna das prabhu @BhaktiYogaAH

In this insightful lecture, Jai Sacinandana Kṛṣṇa Dāsa explores the profound journey of sense control and spiritual identity. He contrasts the mechanical methods of Ashtanga Yoga, like Pratyahara and Pranayama, with the devotional approach of Bhakti Yoga. Discover how to truly turn your mind inward, understand your spiritual self, and offer your senses in loving service to Krishna, rather than merely avoiding material pain. This class emphasizes the critical role of active surrender and heartfelt prayer in achieving genuine Krishna consciousness.

Key Teachings:
• How to turn the mind inward to perceive the soul distinct from the body.
• The limitations of mechanical sense control (Pratyahara) for lasting spiritual progress.
• The devotional perspective of renunciation: offering oneself as the 'bhogya' (enjoyed) to Krishna, the 'bhokta' (enjoyer).
• The importance of active surrender and begging Krishna for assistance in directing the senses.
• Why attentive hearing from pure devotees is essential for cultivating love and controlling the mind.
• The "dangerous position" of spiritual complacency and the need for intense devotion.

Sanskrit Terms Explained:
• Pratyahara: Withdrawal of senses from their objects.
• Ahara: Enjoyment or 'eating' by the senses.
• Bhogya & Bhokta: The enjoyed object and the enjoyer.
• Vignyapti: Humble petition or prayer to the Lord.
• Yuktatama: The most perfectly situated yogi (pure devotee).

Practical Applications:
• Consciously redirect senses towards Krishna while chanting and performing daily activities.
• Transform renunciation by actively offering all sense enjoyment to Krishna as the Supreme Enjoyer.
• Engage in regular, heartfelt prayer (vignyapti) to Krishna, begging for help in overcoming material attachments.
• Prioritize attentive hearing from pure devotees to awaken and deepen your love for Krishna.

Dive deep into the wisdom of the Bhagavad Gita and transform your spiritual practice. If you found this lecture beneficial, please like, share, and subscribe for more profound teachings on Krishna consciousness.
